<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. When letters of credit are posted, exposure is not reduced; it is shifted to a
  more creditworthy entity. As of September 30, 2007, Power had 125 active counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=item4>ITEM 4. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures which are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be
  disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms and that material information relating to each company, including their respective
  consolidated subsidiaries, is accumulated and communicated to the respective company&#146;s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each company by others within
  those entities to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established a disclosure committee (the &#147;committee&#148;) which is made up of several key
  management employees and which reports directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure
  controls and procedures.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures as of the end of the period
  covered by the quarterly report and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance during the period covered in this
  quarterly report on Form 10-Q.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Changes in Internal Controls</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings continually review their respective disclosure controls and procedures and make changes, as necessary, to ensure the quality of their financial reporting.
  There have been no changes in internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the third quarter for PSEG,</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">79</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G and Power that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, each registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the third quarter, significant changes to internal control over financial reporting at Energy Holdings were made. Specifically, Energy Holdings enhanced the controls around reconciliation
  processes within the accounting and treasury functions relative to the classification of Long-Term Debt on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. These controls will be evaluated as part of the overall
  assessment of internal controls over financial reporting to be included in Energy Holdings&#146; 2007 Annual Report.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">80</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=partii>PART II. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item1>ITEM 1. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Certain information reported under Item 3 of Part I of the 2006 Annual Report on Form 10-K and under Item 1 of Part II of the Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarters ended March 31, 2007
  and June 30, 2007 is updated below.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Electric Discount and Energy Competition Act (Competition Act)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 66 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 77.</I></B> On April 23, 2007, PSE&amp;G and Transition Funding were served with a copy of a purported class action complaint
  (Complaint) challenging the constitutional validity of certain provisions of New Jersey&#146;s Competition Act, seeking injunctive relief against continued collection from PSE&amp;G&#146;s electric customers of the
  transition bond charge (TBC) of PSE&amp;G Transition Funding, as well as recovery of TBC amounts previously collected. Notice of the filing of the Complaint was also provided to New Jersey&#146;s Attorney
  General. Under New Jersey law, the Competition Act, enacted in 1999, is presumed constitutional. On July 9, 2007, the same plaintiff filed an amended Complaint to also seek injunctive relief from
  continued collection of related taxes as well as recovery of such taxes previously collected and also filed a petition with the BPU requesting review and adjustment to PSE&amp;G&#146;s recovery of the same charges.
  PSE&amp;G and Transition Funding filed a motion to dismiss the amended Complaint (or in the alternative for summary judgment) on July 30, 2007 and PSE&amp;G filed on September 30, 2007 a motion with the
  BPU to dismiss the petition. On October 10, 2007, PSE&amp;G and Transition Funding&#146;s motion to dismiss was granted. PSE&amp;G&#146;s motion to dismiss the BPU petition is pending.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Con Edison</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 46 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 66 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 77. </I></B>In November 2001, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (Con Edison) filed
  a complaint against PSE&amp;G, PJM and NYISO with FERC asserting a failure to comply with agreements between PSE&amp;G and Con Edison covering 1,000 MW of transmission. PSE&amp;G denied the allegations set
  forth in the complaint. An Initial Decision issued by an ALJ in April 2002 upheld PSE&amp;G&#146;s claim in part but also accepted Con Edison&#146;s contentions in part. In December 2002, FERC issued an order
  modifying the Initial Decision and remanding a number of issues to the ALJ for additional hearings, including issues related to the development of protocols to implement the findings of the order and
  regarding Phase II of the complaint. The ALJ issued an Initial Decision on the Phase II issues in June 2003 and in August 2004, FERC issued its decision on Phase II issues. While those decisions were
  largely favorable to PSE&amp;G, PSE&amp;G sought rehearing as to certain issues, as did Con Edison. On April 19, 2007, the FERC rejected the rehearing requests of both Con Edison and PSE&amp;G, while granting
  PSE&amp;G&#146;s requested clarification that 400 MW of the 1000 MW at issue will have higher priority over other non-firm transactions only if Con Ed agrees to pay congestion costs. Both Con Edison and PSE&amp;G
  have appealed the FERC&#146;s rulings on both Phase I and Phase II issues to the Court of Appeals; thus, it is difficult to predict the final outcome of this proceeding at this time.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The August 2004 order required that PJM, NYISO, Con Edison and PSE&amp;G meet for the purpose of developing operational protocols to implement FERC&#146;s directives. On February 18, 2005, NYISO,
  PJM and PSE&amp;G submitted a joint compliance filing pursuant to FERC&#146;s August 2004 decision. FERC approved the joint proposals on May 18, 2005 and they took effect on July 1, 2005. In subsequent filings
  to FERC regarding the efficacy of these protocols, Con Edison continued to claim that the obligations under the agreements as interpreted by the FERC&#146;s orders were not being met. In December 30, 2005
  and January 19, 2007 filings with FERC, Con Edison claimed to have incurred $111 million in damages, and requested FERC to require refunds of this amount. On April 19, 2007, however, the FERC
  issued an order rejecting Con Edison&#146;s claim for a refund. FERC also rejected Con Edison&#146;s request for interim remedies and directed that no further informational filings regarding the protocols would be
  required. On May 21, 2007, Con Edison sought rehearing of the April 19, 2007 order, which rehearing request was denied by the FERC on August 15, 2007. This matter is still subject to appeal and
  therefore, a final outcome of this proceeding cannot be</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">81</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">predicted. It is anticipated, nonetheless, that additional meetings will be held for the purpose of attempting to resolve issues associated with the operating protocols.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">See information on the following proceedings at the pages indicated for PSEG and each of PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings as noted:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >

      Environmental Protection Agency entitled National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System&#151;Final Regulations to Establish Requirements for Cooling Water Intake Structures at Phase II
      Existing Facilities, now transferred to and venued in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit with Docket No. 04-6696-ag.</FONT></P></TD>

  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(8)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Page 30. (Energy Holdings) Italian government investigation regarding allegations of violations of Bioenergie S.p.A&#146;s air permit for the San Marco facility.</FONT></P></TD>

<P align="center" style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item1a>ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">There are no additional risk factors to be added to the Risk Factors disclosed beginning on page 34 of the 2006 Form 10-K, as updated on page 78 of the Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter
  ended June 30, 2007.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=p2item5>ITEM 5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Certain information reported under the 2006 Annual Report on Form 10-K and the Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarters ended March 31, 2007 and June 30, 2007 is updated below.
  Additionally, certain information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2006 Annual Report on Form 10-K and Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q for the quarters ended
  March 31, 2007 and June 30, 2007. References are to the related pages on the Form 10-K and Form 10-Q as printed and distributed.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Federal Regulation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Transmission Rates and Cost Allocation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">FERC Order 888/890</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.8mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, Page 71 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 80.</I></B> On May 18, 2006, FERC issued a NOPR seeking comments from the industry on whether reforms are needed to the
  protections that</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">82</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FERC established in its previously-issued Order 888 to prevent undue discrimination and preference in the provision of transmission service. These reforms would be reflected in revisions to FERC&#146;s pro
  forma Open Access Transmission Tariff, which has been incorporated into the tariffs of Transmission Providers and governs the terms and conditions under which transmission owners must provide
  transmission service to all eligible customers. On February 16, 2007, FERC issued Final Rule 890 in this proceeding. The Final Rule covers many transmission-related topics and emphasizes the issues of
  transmission planning and cost allocation associated with the construction of transmission projects. On March 19, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a Request for Rehearing and Clarification of the Final Rule, arguing that
  FERC, among other things, erred in appearing to mandate Transmission Provider planning for economic transmission projects and in establishing cost allocation principles for these projects. Order 890
  remains subject to rehearing. The Final Rule requires Transmission Providers, including PJM and the NYISO, to demonstrate compliance with open access principles, including having a transparent
  transmission planning process. PSE&amp;G and Power are actively working with PJM and the NYISO to develop appropriate Order 890 compliance proposals in the area of transmission planning and cost
  allocation; these proposals will be filed with FERC on December 7, 2007. The final outcome of this proceeding and the resulting impact on PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power cannot be determined at this time.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Market Power, Market Design and Capacity Issues</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Market Power</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 17 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 71 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 80.</I></B> Under FERC regulations, public utilities may sell power at cost-based rates or apply to
  FERC for authority to sell at market-based rates (MBR). FERC requires that holders of MBR tariffs file an update every 3 years demonstrating that they continue to lack market power. On June 21, 2007,
  the FERC issued a Final Rule codifying new market-based rate regulations and announcing changes to its market power test. Specifically, the regulations adopt a revised, two-pronged horizontal and
  vertical market power analysis. Moreover, with respect to the use of a relevant geographic market for evaluating whether an entity possesses horizontal market power, the FERC has now established that, in
  circumstances where there has been a specific finding of a relevant sub-market within an RTO, the sub-market may become the geographic market. PJM-East (Eastern MAAC), PSEG North and
  southwestern Connecticut are all mentioned in the Final Rule as submarkets in PJM and the ISO-New England. While the use of these markets for the market power analysis is rebuttable&#150;one can
  demonstrate that their use is not appropriate&#150;the possibility exists that a small sub-market of Eastern MAAC, PSEG North or southwestern Connecticut, in which Power holds a concentration of generation
  assets, could be used in evaluating whether the Power generation assets possess market power. In this case, Power would likely be required to file mitigation measures with FERC. The Final Rule provides
  for certain categories of cost-based, behavioral mitigation measures but also allows an applicant to propose an alternate mitigation plan. Under the schedule set forth in the Final MBR Rule, PSE&amp;G and
  ER&amp;T (with respect to the PJM assets) will be required to file an updated market power study with FERC in December 2007, with Power Connecticut filing an updated market power study in June 2008.
  Energy Holdings&#146; subsidiary GWF Energy LLC, which sells power at market-based rates, will also be required to file an updated market power study. On July 23, 2007, PSE&amp;G and Power filed a request for
  rehearing with FERC, which request is still pending. The outcome of these proceedings cannot be predicted.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On September 20, 2007, the FERC issued an order on two complaints filed against PJM in April 2007 regarding PJM&#146;s alleged interference with the activities of its Market Monitoring Unit (MMU). In
  this Order, which is currently on rehearing, the FERC made a preliminary finding that the MMU had effectively discharged its duties under the Tariff. However, the FERC also found that the Tariff should
  be revised so that the MMU no longer reports to PJM management but instead reports to either the PJM Board of Managers or an independent committee of the PJM Board. The FERC also established
  settlement procedures to address issues concerning the MMU&#146;s structure and functionality. The settlement process has commenced and must be completed in 90 days. PSE&amp;G and Power were parties to the
  underlying complaint proceeding at FERC and are actively participating in the settlement proceeding. Power and PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding at this time.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">83</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:1.4mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">PJM Reliability Pricing Model (RPM)</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.8mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 18 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 72</I></B> <B><I>and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 79.</I></B> On August 31, 2005, PJM filed its RPM with FERC. The RPM constitutes a locational
  installed capacity market design for the PJM region, including a forward auction for installed capacity priced according to a downward-sloping demand curve and a transitional implementation of the market
  design. Parties to the FERC proceeding reached a settlement, which was filed with FERC on September 29, 2006. On December 22, 2006, FERC issued an order approving the September 29 settlement,
  with certain conditions. The final revenue impact on Power of the settlement approved in the December 22, 2006 FERC order could result in incremental margin of $125 million to $175 million in 2007, with
  higher increases in future years as the full year impact is realized and existing capacity contracts expire. On January 22, 2007, PSEG as well as other parties to the proceeding filed for rehearing of the
  December 22, 2006 order and on June 25, 2007, the FERC issued an order denying rehearing with respect to both the April 20, 2006 order and the December 22, 2006 order while granting limited
  clarifications. On August 23, 2007, PSEG filed an appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals of the underlying FERC orders and thus is unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In a related matter, on September 13, 2007, Duquesne Light Company (Duquesne) filed a complaint against PJM, requesting that the FERC order PJM to exclude load in the Duquesne zone from
  upcoming RPM auctions establishing future capacity obligations. Power and PSE&amp;G protested Duquesne&#146;s complaint, arguing that Duquesne should not be allowed to have its load excluded from RPM until
  (i) it officially withdraws as a member from PJM through a FERC proceeding and (ii) FERC accepts such withdrawal. On September 28, 2007, the FERC dismissed Duquesne&#146;s complaint against PJM.
  Thus, the Duquesne zone will remain part of the RPM auction process until such time as the FERC authorizes Duquesne&#146;s withdrawal from PJM.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For additional information, see Item 2. Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Power&#151;Overview and Future Outlook.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">DOE Congestion Study</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 19, March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 72 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 81.</I></B> On August 8, 2006, the DOE issued a National Electric Transmission Congestion Study
  (Congestion Study), as directed by Congress in the Energy Policy Act. This Congestion Study identified two areas in the U.S. as &#147;critical congestion areas;&#148; one of the areas is the region between New York
  and Washington, D.C. Under the EP Act, the DOE has the statutory ability to designate transmission corridors in these &#147;critical congestion areas,&#148; to which FERC back-stop eminent domain authority will
  attach in the event that the relevant State siting agency denies a siting application, does not have the authority to act or fails to act on the siting application within one (1) year. Thus, corridor designation
  may facilitate the construction of transmission projects to address congestion in these corridors.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On October 2, 2007, the DOE issued a report designating the Mid-Atlantic Area National Corridor as a final corridor designation covering most of PJM. Specifically, the final corridor encompasses all
  of New Jersey, as well as portions of West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, the District of Columbia, Delaware, Ohio and New York. This corridor designation has a duration of twelve (12) years.
  The DOE report is subject to rehearing; thus the final outcome of this proceeding cannot be predicted at this time. Should the Mid-Atlantic Area corridor designation remain intact, entities seeking to build
  transmission within its geographic scope, which includes New Jersey, most of Pennsylvania and New York, will be able to use FERC&#146;s back-stop eminent domain authority in the future, if necessary.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>State Regulation</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>New Jersey Energy Master Plan</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.8mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 22 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 73 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 82.</I></B> The Governor of New Jersey has directed the BPU, in partnership with other New Jersey
  agencies, to develop an Energy Master Plan (EMP). State law in New Jersey requires that an EMP be developed every three years, the purpose of which is to ensure safe, secure and reasonably-priced
  energy supply, foster economic growth and development and protect the environment. In the Governor&#146;s directive regarding the</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">84</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">EMP, the Governor established three specific goals: (1) reduce the State&#146;s projected energy use by 20% by the year 2020; (2) supply 20% of the State&#146;s electricity needs with certain renewable energy
  sources by 2020; and (3) emphasize energy efficiency, conservation and renewable energy resources to meet future increases in New Jersey electric demand without increasing New Jersey&#146;s reliance on non-
  renewable resources. In November 2006, PSE&amp;G submitted a number of strategies designed to improve efficiencies in customer use and increase the level of renewable generation. During January and
  February 2007, PSE&amp;G has been actively involved in the broad-based constituent working groups created to develop specific strategies to achieve the goals and objectives. In September 2007, the BPU held a
  stakeholder meeting on energy efficiency issues, and PSE&amp;G submitted comments advocating a strong role for gas and electric utilities in meeting the State&#146;s energy efficiency goals. A draft EMP is expected
  to be released in November of 2007, and a final plan is expected to be completed early in 2008. The outcome of this proceeding and its impact on PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power cannot be predicted at this time.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On
    April 19, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a plan with the BPU designed to spur investment
    in solar power in New Jersey and meet energy goals under the EMP. Under the
    plan, PSE&amp;G would invest approximately
  $100 million over two years following BPU approval of the plan to help finance
    the installation of solar systems throughout its service area. If approved
    by the BPU, the initiative could begin by the end of 2007 and support 30
    MW of solar power in the following two years, fulfilling approximately 50%
    of the BPU&#146;s Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) requirements in PSE&amp;G&#146;s
    service area for 2009 and 2010. On July 12, 2007, the BPU established a schedule
    for consideration of this proposal. PSE&amp;G has held a series of stakeholder
    meetings to discuss program details with interested parties. Evidentiary
    hearings, if necessary, are scheduled for December 2007. The outcome of this
    proceeding cannot be predicted at this time.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>BGSS Filings</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 23 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 73 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 82.</I></B> PSE&amp;G made its 2006/2007 BGSS filing on May 26, 2006. The parties entered into a
  Stipulation to make the filed BGSS rate effective October 1, 2006 on a provisional basis. However, since the time of the filing, prices of gas futures have dropped significantly and as a result, additional
  BGSS data has been requested by and provided to the BPU. Settlement discussions with the BPU Staff were completed and a new Stipulation, dated October 27, 2006, was executed by the parties. This new
  Stipulation was approved by the BPU and resulted in a decrease in annual BGSS revenues of approximately $120 million, which is approximately a 6% reduction in a typical residential gas customer&#146;s bill.
  The new BGSS rate became effective on November 9, 2006. The Stipulation did not include any change in the Balancing Charge, which is a charge for the difference between the amount of gas delivered to
  customers and the amount of gas used.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The parties entered into a second Stipulation, which addresses the Balancing Charge only. The BPU Staff recommended a lower Balancing Charge than proposed by PSE&amp;G and received agreement
  from Rate Counsel. The parties executed the Stipulation for the lower rate and BPU approval was received on January 17, 2007.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The parties entered into a third Stipulation to make both the BGSS rate and the Balancing Charge, which were previously approved on a provisional basis, final. In addition, the Stipulation included
  agreement between the parties on the following two items: 1) PSE&amp;G agreed to consider, on a prospective basis, some suggested changes to the gas hedging program; and 2) PSE&amp;G agreed to increase the gas
  reservation charge from 27.4 cents per dekatherm (DTh) to 42.5 cents per DTh to be effective the first month after final BPU approval. This Stipulation was approved by the Administrative Law Judge on
  May 21, 2007 and then by the BPU at its Agenda Meeting of June 14, 2007.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G made its 2007/2008 BGSS filing on June 1, 2007. In the filing, PSE&amp;G requested an increase in annual BGSS revenues of $39 million, excluding Sales and Use Tax, to be effective October 1, 2007.
  This increase amounts to approximately 2% for a typical residential customer. No other changes were included in the filing. On July 2, 2007, the BPU transferred the case to the Office of Administrative
  Law (OAL) for its initial decision. PSE&amp;G has received and responded to discovery from both BPU staff and Rate Counsel and 3 Public Hearings have been held. PSE&amp;G has the ability to put in place two
  self-implementing BGSS increases on December 1, 2007 and February 1, 2008 of up to 5% and also may reduce the BGSS rate at any&nbsp;time.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">85</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Remediation Adjustment Clause (RAC) Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 23 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 74 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 83.</I></B> In February 2007, PSE&amp;G submitted its RAC-13 and RAC-14 filings with the BPU, seeking
  recovery of $71 million of RAC program costs incurred during the two-year period, August 1, 2004 through July 31, 2006, were reasonable and are available for recovery.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On April 18, 2007, the BPU transferred the case to the OAL for its initial decision. On October 12, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a settlement agreement with the ALJ, resolving this matter. On October 25, 2007,
  the BPU issued an Order approving settlement of the matter and affirming recovery of PSE&amp;G&#146;s RAC 13 and 14 costs of $43 million and $28 million, respectively. Amortization of the program costs is equal
  to revenues with no impact on Net Income.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Societal Benefits Clause (SBC) Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006
        Form 10-K, Page 24 v and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 74 and June 30,
        2007 Form 10-Q, page 83.</I></B> On May 7, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a motion
        with the BPU seeking approval of changes in its electric and gas SBC
        rates and its electric non-utility generation transition charge (NGC)
        rates. For electric customers, the rates proposed were designed to recover
        approximately $270 million in SBC/NGC revenues beginning January 1, 2008.
        For gas, the rates proposed were designed to recover approximately $75
        million in SBC/NGC revenues. On June 7, 2007, the BPU transferred this
        matter to the OAL for its initial decision and the discovery process
        has begun. On October 17, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed an updated motion with
        the BPU. This revision sought to recover approximately $310 million and
        $75 million in SBC/NGC revenues for electric and gas customers, respectively.
        Hearings are scheduled for the first quarter of 2008. SBC costs are deferred
        when incurred and amortized to expense when recovered in revenues, resulting
        in no impact on Net Income.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Gas Purchasing Strategies Audit</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G and Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>2006 Form 10-K, Page 2 and March 31, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 74 and June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 83.</I></B> In January 2007, the BPU issued an RFP to solicit bid proposals to engage a contractor to
  perform an analysis of the gas purchasing practices and hedging strategies of the four New Jersey gas distribution companies (GDCs), including PSE&amp;G. The primary focus of the audit is to examine and
  compare the financial and physical hedging policies and practices of each GDC and to provide recommendations for improvements to these policies and practices. Over the past few months, the audit has
  proceeded with discovery and the conducting of interviews. The goal of the consultants is to issue a report of major recommendations by the end of the year. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this
  process.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Universal Service Fund (USF) Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>June 30, 2007 Form 10-Q, page 83</I></B>. The USF is an energy assistance program mandated by the BPU under the Competition Act to provide payment assistance to low-income customers. The Lifeline
  program is also a mandated energy assistance program to provide payment assistance to elderly and disabled customers. On June 29, 2007, PSE&amp;G filed a compliance filing on behalf of all of the State&#146;s
  electric and gas public utilities to reset statewide rates for the Permanent Universal Service Fund and the Lifeline program. The filed rates were set to recover $172 million on a statewide basis. Of this
  amount, the revised electric rates would recover $95 million while the revised gas rates would recover $77 million. As part of this filing, the proposed rates for the Lifeline program are expected to recover a
  total of $77 million, $50 million for the electric program and $27 million for the gas program. On October 4, 2007, the New Jersey BPU issued an order allowing the utilities to recover $174 million ($96
  million electric and $78 million gas) on a statewide basis. This exceeds the requested amount and is based on updates reflecting 10 months of actual data. The proposed rates for the Lifeline program were
  adopted as filed. The new rates became effective on October 4, 2007. PSE&amp;G earns no margin on the collection of the USF and Lifeline programs, resulting in no impact on Net Income.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">86</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

    <TD align="center"><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">

D</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.8mm; ">I</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">R</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.8mm; ">ISIO</FONT>
    <P align="left" style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 1mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="center" style="width:100%; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Derek M. DiRisio<br>Vice President and Controller<br>(Principal Accounting Officer)</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

<P align="center">
<FONT face="serif">iv</FONT></P>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=4>



<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="center">
<B><FONT face="serif">PURCHASE AND SALE AGREEMENT</FONT></B></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">This PURCHASE AND SALE AGREEMENT is made as of September 17, 2007 (this &#147;Agreement&#148;) by and among: </FONT></P>
<table width="100%"  border="0">
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">SN Power Peru Holding S.R.L., a Peruvian sociedad
    de responsabilidad limitada (&#147;Purchaser&#148;); </FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(b)</FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">solely for purposes of Section 11.08, Statkraft Norfund
        Power Invest AS, a company incorporated under the laws of Norway and
    the indirect parent of Purchaser (&#147;Purchaser Parent&#148;);</FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(c) </FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">PSEG Americas Ltd., a Bermuda company (&#147;Seller&#148;); </FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(d)</FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">solely for purposes of Section 11.09, PSEG Global
    L.L.C., a New Jersey limited liability company (&#147;Seller Parent&#148;);</FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(e)</FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">Transamerica Energy Company, a Cayman Islands company
    (&#147;TEC&#148;); and</FONT></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td>&nbsp;</td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" nowrap><FONT face="serif">(f)</FONT></td>
    <td><FONT face="serif">solely for the purposes of Sections 2.07 and 9.04,
    Electroandes S.A., a Peruvian sociedad anonima.</FONT></td>
  </tr>
</table>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT face="serif">WITNESSETH:</FONT></B></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, the Government of Peru desired to privatize the four hydroelectric facilities of Empresa Minera del Centro del Per&#250; S.A. (&#147;CENTROMIN&#148;) which were owned and operated by
CENTROMIN&#146;s subsidiary Empresa de Electr&iacute;cidad de los Andes S.A., a Peruvian sociedad anonima (&#147;Original Electroandes&#148;); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, Inversiones Elegia S.R.L. (&#147;IES&#148;) was formed on February 15, 2001 to bid to acquire Original Electroandes from CENTROMIN; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, on December 11, 2001, IES and CENTROMIN entered into a contract (the &#147;Privatization Agreement&#148;) pursuant to which IES would acquire 99.6744% of Original Electroandes from CENTROMIN
(the balance of ownership being acquired by employees of Original Electroandes) and IES would make certain investments in Original Electroandes; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, in connection with the Privatization Agreement, on December 11, 2001, IES executed a Juridical Stability Agreement with the Government of Peru, as recipient of an equity investment of the
Seller and TEC (the &#147;IES Stability Agreement&#148;), related primarily to Peruvian income tax rates; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, Seller and TEC also entered into separate Juridical Stability Agreements with the Government of Peru, both dated December 11, 2001 (each, an &#147;Investment Stability Agreement&#148;),
related primarily to Peruvian income tax rates on dividends;</FONT></P>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=4>



<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, by an agreement of asociaci&oacute;n en participaci&oacute;n dated December 6, 2001 (as amended on December 31, 2002, February 25, 2005 and August 17, 2006, the &#147;AenP Agreement&#148;),
Seller, the owner of 20.40% of the equity interests of IES (the &#147;PSEG Americas Stake&#148;) and TEC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Seller and the owner of 79.59% of the equity</FONT></P>
<P align="center">
<FONT face="serif">2</FONT></P>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=4>



<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="left">
<FONT face="serif">interests of IES (the &#147;TEC Stake&#148;) formed a Peruvian asociaci&oacute;n en participaci&oacute;n (&#147;AenP&#148;) with respect to their ownership and operation of IES; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, on May 7, 2002, IES was reconstituted from a sociedad comercial de responsabilidad limitada, or S.R.L., into a sociedad an&oacute;nima and thereafter renamed &#147;Electroandes S.A.&#148;
(&#147;Electroandes&#148;); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, on June 1, 2002, Original Electroandes was merged into Electroandes; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, during the course of 2003, Electroandes made three separate issuances of bonds, and, in connection therewith, trusts were created on all of the assets and revenue of Electroandes, including
cash flows from revenues, and a pledge of the stock of Electroandes was given by Seller and TEC to secure payment thereof (which pledge was released on October 13, 2005); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, on December 18, 2006 CENTROMIN assigned the Privatization Agreement to Activos Mineros S.A.C.; </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, Purchaser desires to purchase and Seller desires to sell 100% of the capital stock of TEC, the PSEG Americas Stake and Seller&#146;s membership interest in AenP (collectively, the
&#147;Interests&#148;), which will result in Purchaser&#146;s beneficial ownership of 99.99% of Electroandes and Purchaser&#146;s control of 100% of AenP; and </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">WHEREAS, immediately prior to the Closing, Seller and TEC will cause AenP to distribute all of the equity interests held by AenP in PSEG Peru Company, a Cayman Islands company, to TEC, and TEC will,
in turn, distribute all such equity interests to Seller. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">ACCORDINGLY, in consideration of the mutual covenants and agreements set forth in this Agreement and intending to be legally bound, Seller, Purchaser, solely for the purpose of Sections 2.07 and 9.04,
Electroandes, solely for purposes of Section 11.08, Purchaser Parent and, solely for purposes of Section 11.09, Seller Parent, agree as follows: </FONT></P>
<P align="center">
<B><FONT face="serif">ARTICLE I </FONT></B><BR>
<BR>
<B><FONT face="serif">DEFINITIONS </FONT></B></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">Section 1.01.</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Definitions</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">. As used in this Agreement, the following defined terms have the meanings indicated
below. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Action or Proceeding</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any action, tax audit, tax examination, suit, proceeding, arbitration or investigation by or before a
Governmental or Regulatory Authority. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">AenP</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">AenP Agreement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">AenP Transfer of Interest to Purchaser</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; is defined in Section 2.06. </FONT></P>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=4>



<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Affiliate</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any Person that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by or is under
common control with the Person specified. For purposes of this definition, &#147;control&#148; of a Person means the power, direct or indirect, to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of such Person whether through ownership
of voting securities or ownership interests, by Contract or otherwise. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Agreement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the preamble. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Allocated Liabilities</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 9.04.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Antitrust Law</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any applicable antitrust, competition, premerger notification or trade regulation law, regulation or order,
including any such law, regulation or order promulgated by INDECOPI. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Audited Financial Statements</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the balance sheet of Electroandes as of December 31, 2006 audited by Deloitte, and the related
statements of operations, changes in net worth and cash flow for the fiscal year then ended, including all notes thereto. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Bringdown Date</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 7.01.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Business Day</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means a day other than Saturday, Sunday or any day on which banks located in Lima, Peru or New York, New York are
authorized or obligated to close. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Capital Expenditures</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the amount of capital expenditures paid by Electroandes with respect to the Yaupi Expansion Project
for a given period.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Capital Gain Tax</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.07. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Capital Gain Tax Return</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.07.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">CENTROMIN</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the closing of the transactions contemplated by Section 2.01.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Capex</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the amount of Capital Expenditures for the period beginning on July 1, 2007 and ending on the Closing Date.
</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Capex Statement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.05(a) .</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Date</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means:</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">before the Closing occurs the 3rd Business Day following the date on which the last of the conditions set forth in Articles VII and VIII
are satisfied or waived by Purchaser or Seller, respectively as permitted thereunder; and </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">such date as Seller and Purchaser effect the Closing. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Debt</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the amount of Debt as of the Closing Date.</FONT></P>

<HR noshade align="center" width="100%" size=4>



<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Debt Statement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.05(a) .</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Statements</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.05(a) . </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Working Capital</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the Working Capital as of the close of business in Peru on the Closing Date, prepared on a basis
consistent with the preparation of the statement set forth on Exhibit A attached hereto. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Closing Working Capital Statement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.05(a) . </FONT></P>
<P align="left">

<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Good Utility Practices</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the practices, methods and acts engaged in by a significant portion of the hydroelectric industry in
Peru that, at a particular time, in the exercise of reasonable judgment in light of the facts known at the time a decision was made, would have been expected to accomplish the desired result in a manner consistent with good hydroelectric power
industry practices in Peru, the requirements of all applicable Laws of the Governmental or Regulatory Authorities of Peru, economy and expedition. Good Utility Practices are not intended to be limited to the optimum practices, methods or acts to the
exclusion of all others but rather to include a spectrum of possible practices, methods or acts generally accepted in Peru during the relevant period in light of the circumstances. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Government Lists</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means, collectively, the following lists maintained by the United States government: </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">the two lists maintained by the United States Department of Commerce (Denied Persons and Entities; the Denied Persons list can be found at
http://www.bis.doc.gov/dpl/Default.htm; the Entity List can be found at http://www.bis.doc.gov/Entities/Default.htm); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">the two lists maintained by the United States Department of the Treasury (Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons; both lists
can be found at http://www.ustreas.gov/offices/eotffc/ofac/sdn/t1lsdn.pdf); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">the two lists maintained by the United States Department of State (Terrorist Organizations and Debarred Parties; the Terrorists
Organizations list can be found at http://www.state.gov/s/ct/rls/fs/37191.htm; the Debarred Persons list can be found at http://www.pmdtc.org/debar059.htm); </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">the list maintained by Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering (this list can be found at
http://www1.oecd.org/fatf/pdf/40Recs-2003_en.pdf); and </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(e)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">any other list of terrorists, terrorist organizations or narcotics traffickers maintained pursuant to any of the rules and regulations of

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Post-Closing Period</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any taxable period (or portion thereof) beginning after the date of the Closing. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Pre-Closing Period</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any taxable period (or portion thereof) ending on or prior to the date of the Closing. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Privatization Agreement</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Properties</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means, as to any Person, all assets and properties of every kind, nature, character and description (whether real or
personal, whether tangible or intangible) of such Person. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">PSEG Americas Stake</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Purchase Price</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.02. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Purchaser</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the preamble. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Purchaser Indemnified Party</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 9.05.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Purchaser Parent</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the preamble. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Representatives</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means, as to any Person, its officers, directors, employees, partners, members, stockholders, counsel,
accountants, financial advisers, engineers and consultants. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Seller</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the preamble. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Seller Approvals</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 3.04(a) . </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Seller Indemnified Party</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 9.04.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Seller&#146;s Disclosure Schedule</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the lists, descriptions, exceptions and other information and materials set forth on the
attached Schedule A. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Settlement Date</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 2.05(c) .</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Side Letter</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the side letter between Seller and Purchaser Parent executed on the date hereof. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">SUNAT</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the Peruvian Superintendencia Nacional de Administraci&oacute;n Tributaria.</FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">SUNAT Deductibility Proceeding</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means that certain controversy brought by SUNAT in July 2005, against Electroandes claiming past
due taxes for 2002, totaling approximately &#36;2,000,000 (including interest) as a result of deducting a portion of the interest on</FONT></P>

<p style="page-break-before:always"></p><PAGE>


<P align="left">
<FONT face="serif">loans originally granted by non-domestic entities to IES for the acquisition of shares of Electroandes. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">SUNAT Follow-On Dispute</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 3.09 of Seller&#146;s Disclosure Schedule.</FONT><FONT size=2 face="sans-serif"> </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Straddle Period</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any taxable period beginning on or prior to the date of the Closing and ending after the date of the
Closing. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Takeover Date</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; is the date of the notarization of the actual transfer of 99.6744% in Original Electroandes to IES. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Tax</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any and all federal, state, provincial, local, foreign and other taxes, levies, imposts, duties, and similar
governmental charges in the nature of a tax (including any interest, fines, assessments, penalties or additions to tax imposed in connection therewith or with respect thereto) including: </FONT></P>
<P align="left" style="margin-left:25px;">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">taxes imposed on, or measured by, income, franchise, profits or gross receipts; and </FONT></P>
<P align="left" style="margin-left:25px;">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT face="sans-serif"> </FONT><FONT face="serif">ad valorem, value added, capital gains, sales, goods and services, use, real or personal property, capital stock, license, branch, payroll,
estimated withholding, employment, social security (or similar), unemployment, compensation, utility, severance, production, excise, stamp, occupation, premium, windfall profits, transfer and gains taxes, and customs duties. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Tax Return</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means any return, report, information return, declaration, claim for refund, election, disclosure, estimate,
information report or return, or other document, together with all schedules, attachments, amendments and supplements thereto (including all related or supporting information), supplied to or required to be supplied to any Governmental or Regulatory
Authority with respect to Taxes. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">TEC</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the preamble. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">TEC Stake</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in the recitals. </FONT></P>
<P align="left">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">Third Party Claim</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; has the meaning given to that term in Section 9.07(b) .</FONT></P>
<P align="left">

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT face="serif">&#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">U.S. Dollars</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; or &#147;</FONT><U><FONT face="serif">&#36;</FONT></U><FONT face="serif">&#148; means the lawful currency of the United States. </FONT></P>

<P align="left">

forth on Exhibit A. </FONT></P>
